newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: EU governments take 41.7 pct of GDP in 1995.
newsitem.headline: EU governments take 41.7 pct of GDP in 1995.

text.p: Taxes and social contributions in the European Union consumed an average of 41.7 percent of Gross Domestic Product in 1995, matching a peak set in 1993, Eurostat, the EU's statistical office said on Thursday.

The latest ranking of how much EU governments take from their economies put Sweden on top at a rate of 51.5 percent, while Britain and Spain came in at the bottom among the 15-member bloc at 34.9 and 34.8 percent, respectively.
Denmark, which has the highest tax and lowest social contributions' ratio in the EU -- 49.7 percent and 1.6 percent -- was just behind Sweden in the overall ranking at 51.4 percent.
The report also noted that Denmark had by far the highest ratio of taxes on income and wealth at 31.6 percent of GDP and of VAT at 9.3 percent.
France, meanwhile, recorded the lowest ratio of taxes on income and wealth at 9.5 percent and was the highest in terms of social contributions -- 19.3 percent.
Germany, France, Britain and Italy -- the EU's four largest economies -- accounted for almost three-quarters of EU tax revenue, the report added.
Following are the ratios for 13 countries, with figures for Greece and Portugal not immediately available: (percent)
